title: Manhattan Luxury Housing Closes 14th Straight Week of Slow Dealmaking
text:
Fourteen luxury homes in Manhattan went into contract in the seven days ending Sunday, a decent number given the Jewish New Year made it a three-day work week for many New Yorkers, according to a round-up from Olshan Realty on Monday.



Nevertheless, it marked the 14th straight week that contracts for Manhattan homes asking $4 million or more fell below 20, the benchmark Olshan uses to signal a strong market.



More: Compass’s ‘Chief Evangelist’ on the Importance of a Home’s Context

Deals to Sunday rang in at $118 million, roughly $10 million less than the previous week.



The most expensive home to find a buyer was a three-bedroom condo on the 67th floor of One57, the first supertall to grace the southern edge of Central Park, asking $22 million. It marks a significant loss for the seller, who bought the unit from developer, Extell, in 2015 for a little over $28 million, according to Olshan.



The more than 4,100-square-foot apartment has a living room overlooking Central Park and access to the building’s suite of amenities, including a pool, a library lounge, a fitness center and access to the Park Hyatt hotel services.



The second most expensive home to go into contract last week was an Upper East Side townhouse owned by the French government asking $18.5 million, according to Olshan.



From Penta: 'Devolved Parliament' Sets a Record for Banksy

The Consulate General of France originally put the multi-unit building on the market in Sept. 2017 asking nearly $23 million. The 25-foot-wide, brick and limestone townhouse spans nearly 11,000 square feet and is currently divided into five apartments.
